prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: High-resolution dust continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will resolve the dust continuum emission in 60 ALESS SMGs (covered by 35 pointings) on scales of ~0.1", corresponding to ~820 pc at z~2.5.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For our frequency set-up, we will use the same set-up that we used in Cycle 0 to successfully create our ALMA SMG survey sample: Band 7 TDM, dual-polarization observations centered at 344 GHz and covering the useable 7.5-GHz bandwidth in single continuum mode. A single central frequency for all targets is fine, as our science goals rely only on continuum detections. We do not require any user-defined calibration.

Using the most extended configuration offered as part of 'Standard' Cycle 3 observing (C36-6), we can reach an angular resolution of 0.1" at 870um. This will allow us to probe the obscured star formation on scales of an unprecedented 820 pc at z~2.5, distinguishing between various models for the distribution of the star formation (Fig 3), and to probe star formation rate surface densities between ~3 and >1000 Msun/yr/kpc^2, the threshold for Eddington-limited star formation. The galaxies were all individually unresolved or only marginally resolved in our compact-array (1.6") ALMA Cycle 0 imaging at the same frequency, indicating that the largest angular scale with emission is <1". Moreover, as we already have ALMA compact-array maps of these objects at the same frequency, the potentially missing spacings in this extended configuration are not a concern. Finally, while it is tempting to push down to the highest resolution available for this band (0.04" with C36-7), the last panel of Fig. 3 demonstrates that even with much longer integration times, the requested C36-6 configuration has the optimal uv-coverage for surveying the expected brightness distributions. We therefore request 0.1" resolution with configuration C36-6.

We propose high-resolution 870um mapping of 60 SMGs which were clearly detected but individually unresolved in our compact array (1.6") ALMA Cycle 0 ALESS continuum survey at the same frequency (Hodge et al. 2013b). With the requested configuration (C36-6), and assuming a typical SMG size of ~0.3" (Simpson et al. 2015; Ikarashi et al. 2015), observations of the faintest source in our sample (1.4 mJy) would require an rms of 50 uJy/beam to ensure a S/N>3 per beam (in the limiting case of uniform emission), requiring 15 minutes on-source. On the other hand, if any of the previously unresolved sources turn out to be nuclear starbursts (ie. unresolved at the target resolution), this rms would allow us to achieve S/N values of >25-150 -- high enough to place a conservative upper limit on the true source size of <30-50% of the beam size, or <250-400 pc at z~2.5. We therefore adopt 50uJy/beam as our sensitivity limit, and our time request comes to 8.6 hours on-source for 35 pointings, or a total of 15.8 hours (including calibrations and overheads as estimated by the OT).
If any of our 15 Cycle 1 targets are observed before the completion of Cycle 2, we will descope this project accordingly.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Submillimeter galaxies (SMGs) are extremophiles in the spectrum of high-z star-forming galaxies. Yet despite their enormous luminosities, a number of factors have historically conspired (faintness/dust-obscuration in the optical, limiting resolution of longer wavelength telescopes) to leave few clues as to the nature of their starbursts. With ALMA, the situation is fundamentally changed. The resolution/sensitivity is now such that one can resolve the obscured star-forming regions in SMGs in the rest-frame far-IR at resolutions comparable to the rest-frame optical. To this end, we propose high-resolution (0.1") 870um continuum imaging of 60 ALMA-confirmed SMGs from our Cycle 0 ALESS survey that have deep HST/WFC3 H-band imaging. By spatially resolving the star-forming regions on the same scales as the stellar populations (~1kpc) in a statistically significant sample of galaxies for the first time, we will directly address the two biggest unknowns regarding SMGs: (1) How is their star formation distributed? (2) What is triggering the bursts? This proposal will provide the observational foundation necessary to answer a question that, until now, existed firmly in the realm of theory.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: #2011.1.00294.S: "More than LESS: The first fully-identified submillimeter survey" (PI Smail - accepted and observed) #2012.1.00307.S: "Resolved, direct imaging of the obscured star forming regions in SMGs" (PI Hodge - accepted, but still unobserved) #2013.1.00470.S: "Resolving the star-forming ISM at z~2-3 (PI Hodge - accepted, but still unobserved)
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
